Linux Scripting

Removing Repetitive Tasks

~1 minute read from Dec 20th 2021

Needed something to post, so here‚Äôs some tips to make life on the command line a breeze.

If you use linux, odds are you are either using bash or zsh. In your home folder, bash has a file called .bashrc and zsh has a file called .zshrc. Adding aliases to these files is a great way to make simple shortcuts for long and complicated commands. Here are some examples:

1#Git
2alias add='git add'
3alias commit='git commit'
4alias push='git push'
5alias pull='git pull'
6alias status='git status'
7alias log='git log'
8alias clone='git clone'

Aliases can replace anything you would type into your terminal:

1#Backups
2alias bak='timeshift --check >> ~/Logs/timeshift.log'
3alias restore='timeshift --restore'
4#Scripts
5alias longscript='bash ~/Scripts/LongScript.sh'

Anything you type into the terminal can be turned into a bash script by typing each command line by line into a text file and saving it as a .sh file. All you need to do to run the file is run bash scriptName.sh

Aliases are great, but automatically running scripts don‚Äôt have to be typed on a terminal at all. This can be done with cron, a simple service that can run scripts at specific times, at reboot or login, and every x number of hours/days/minutes.

Install a package from your package manager called cronie or cron. If you can‚Äôt find one of those, look up what your distrobution uses, and install that. Next is to make cron run at startup through systemd. The command is systemctl enable --now cronie (or crond).

Now that crond is setup, running crontab -e will open a text editor that will allow you to add scripts that run automatically.
